keyTakeAways: Federal officials, including Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), are under judicial scrutiny for allegedly violating a judge’s order restricting the use of tear gas and less-lethal force during protests in Chicago.

US District Judge Sara Ellis, an Obama appointee, issued a sweeping order requiring body-worn cameras and limiting crowd control tactics, expressing concern that the Trump administration is not following her directives.

Operation Midway Blitz, a recent ICE deployment targeting migrants in Chicagoland, resulted in over 1,000 arrests and sparked public protests, with allegations that agents deployed tear gas without prior warning.

Federal officials defended their actions, asserting that body-worn cameras are being used and denying reports of tear gas deployment without warning, though they acknowledged not having personally seen such incidents.

Judge Ellis requested testimony from Russell Hott, the former interim head of ICE’s Chicago field office, and Gregory Bovino, CBP chief patrol agent, to provide accountability for field operations despite Hott’s relocation to Washington, DC.

Protests at the Broadview ICE facility continued into October 2025, with over 100 demonstrators gathering and 15 arrests made on both Friday and Saturday, indicating sustained public resistance to immigration enforcement actions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, US District Judge Sara Ellis, an Obama appointee, demanded accountability from federal immigration enforcement agencies—particularly Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE)—after reports surfaced that agents deployed tear gas and pepper balls at protests in Chicago without prior warning. The judge had previously issued a restraining order requiring body-worn cameras and restricting the use of force, but expressed concern that the Trump administration was not complying. A hearing was held where officials, including CBP Deputy Incident Commander Kyle Harvick and ICE Deputy Field Office Director Shawn Byers, testified, denying reports of unapproved tear gas use and asserting compliance with camera mandates. Despite these claims, Judge Ellis requested that Russell Hott, the former ICE Chicago field office head, and Gregory Bovino, CBP chief patrol agent, be deposed to provide direct testimony on field operations. This came amid ongoing protests at the Broadview ICE facility, which saw over 100 demonstrators and more than 30 arrests between September and October 2025, demonstrating sustained public opposition to immigration enforcement actions under Operation Midway Blitz, which resulted in over 1,000 arrests across Illinois.
title: Federal officials try to reassure judge they’re following her orders to tone down and record Chicagoland protest actions
